Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neural Dynamics of Variability and Robustness in a Motor Pattern Generator

A central goal of neuroscience research is to understand how the nervous system reliably generates rhythmic motor behaviors, including breathing, locomotion, biting and swallowing. These behaviors are important for survival, and must be robust to noise and environmental uncertainty. Furthermore, animals need to flexibly control these behaviors in order to pursue various goals or respond to stimuli. This project will investigate the hypothesis that the robustness and flexibility of motor control emerges in part due to intrinsic variability in the neural and motor activity, along with modulation by noisy sensory inputs. This investigation will utilize a combined experimental and mathematical approach, using the marine mollusk Aplysia californica as a model system. Experiments will involve the direct activation and inhibition of specific neurons in the isolated buccal mass of Aplysia, in order to better determine the role of these neurons in controlling motor behavior. These experiments will be accompanied by a mathematical investigation into biologically-inspired dynamical structures that could underlie variation, robustness, and flexibility in motor pattern generation.

The impact of this research extends beyond neuroscience and into engineering applications, specifically in regard to the development of robust, biologically-inspired robots and prosthetic devices. In pursuing this research, the fellow will receive training both in computational and mathematical modeling and laboratory experiments involving Aplysia. In addition, the fellow will assist with the development of novel inquiry-based curricula for undergraduate courses, which will emphasize interdisciplinary applications of mathematics and will incorporate the results of the fellow's research as examples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central question of this research was the following - how do animals generate rhythmic motor patterns (swallowing, walking, swimming) that are both robust (remaining effective despite changing environmental conditions) and flexible (capable of adapting in response to relevant sensory information)?. My mentors and I investigated these questions using a combination of mathematical modelling and in vitro experiments. This work focused on the rhythmic feeding motor patterns of the marine mollusk Aplysia californica as a tractable model system.

In our most recent paper, we provided clear, mathematically precise definitions of "robustness" and "flexibility" in the context of motor control, using the language of dynamical systems theory, which we expect will be of broad interest to the field. We then demonstrated that a mathematical model of the Aplysia feeding system exhibites bistability (it could function in two distinct modes), and moreover, that this bistability provided a mechanism by which motor systems could be both robust and flexible, in response to changing task demands. In addition, using in vitro experiments, we collected preliminary data on the response of the Aplysia feeding system to changes in mechanical load during swallowing, which will allow for experimental tests of the predictions of the model.

Our precise characterization of robustness and flexibility adresses a long-standing ambiguity about the use of these terms in the motor control literature. Furthermore, our demonstration of the role of multistable dynamics as a way of facilitating robust and flexible behaviors in multifunctional motor systems is of general interest in the field of motor control. The general insights on motor control that we've developed are likely to be useful across a range of motor control systems, and in the design of control systems for biologically inspired robots, such as the one described in Daltorio et al, 2013, or prosthetic devices.

Our results were presented at both the 2014 and 2015 meetings of the Society for Neuroscience, and are detailed in two peer-reviewed journal articles:

Shaw, K. M., Lyttle, D. N., Gill, J. P., Cullins, M. J., McManus, J. M., Lu, H., ... & Chiel, H. J. (2015). The significance of dynamical architecture for adaptive responses to mechanical loads during rhythmic behavior. Journal of computational neuroscience, 38(1), 25-51.

Lyttle, D. N., Gill, J. P., Shaw, K. M., Thomas, P. J., & Chiel, H. J. (2017). Robustness, flexibility, and sensitivity in a multifunctional motor control model. Biological cybernetics, 111(1), 25-47.
